title: The Covenant Promise
description: Deep theological questions about God's covenant with Noah

questions.text: What is the significance of the rainbow covenant in Genesis 9?

options.text: God's unconditional promise never to destroy the earth by flood again
options.explanation: Genesis 9:11 states 'And I will establish my covenant with you; neither shall all flesh be cut off any more by the waters of a flood; neither shall there any more be a flood to destroy the earth.'

options.text: A conditional promise based on human righteousness
options.explanation: The Noahic covenant is unconditional - it depends on God's faithfulness, not human performance.

options.text: A temporary agreement lasting only Noah's lifetime
options.explanation: Genesis 9:12 calls it an 'everlasting covenant' between God and every living creature.

questions.text: How does the flood narrative demonstrate both God's judgment and mercy?

options.text: Judgment on wickedness, mercy in preserving the righteous remnant
options.explanation: God judged the wickedness of mankind (Gen 6:5-7) but showed mercy by saving Noah and his family, preserving humanity and all creatures.

options.text: Pure judgment with no element of mercy
options.explanation: God's mercy is clearly shown in His preservation of Noah, his family, and all the animals.

options.text: Only mercy with no real judgment
options.explanation: The flood was indeed God's judgment on the wickedness that filled the earth.
